awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Data Integration in Undergraduate Mathematics Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will engage early-stage undergraduate students in the mathematical study of real world problems by using computationally-focused modules that infuse authentic data into the first two years of the undergraduate mathematics curriculum.  The project will focus on four courses: Calculus I, Calculus II, Multivariate Calculus, and Linear Algebra at Rochester Institute of Technology and Nazareth College of Rochester. The leadership team will study the: (i) impact of computer-based modules on undergraduate students' mathematical disposition and achievement and (ii) effectiveness of professional development on undergraduate mathematics faculty.  The project will contribute to the study of data and technology integration in mathematics education at the collegiate level, and will facilitate the uptake of new methods by developing high-quality educational tools for educators to use in their classrooms. In this way, the project will support the National Science Foundation's mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing the national prosperity. 
 
This project will develop in-class modules based on real-world data so that students have authentic experiences that support and motivate the investigation of mathematical concepts and techniques; will study the impact of these modules on undergraduate students' disposition towards and achievement in mathematics; and will study the effect of professional development on undergraduate faculty members.  Students will be given questionnaires and will participate in focus groups, courses will be videotaped, and undergraduate faculty members will be given questionnaires and asked to write reflective journals. There will be roughly 50 professors trained internally and externally, and the project will impact approximately 1,000 students distributed between Rochester Institute of Technology (a technical university) and Nazareth College of Rochester (a comprehensive college). This project will provide information about the ways that encountering authentic data affects students' attitudes and their willingness to engage with computers, and also undergraduate mathematics faculty members' response to professional development activities. The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program will provide co-funding for this project in recognition of its alignment with the broader teacher preparation goals of the Noyce effort.

por.por_cntn:
There has been a national call (Schumacher et al, 2015; Aliaga et al., 2005; Hoyles et al., 2002) for mathematics programs to include data analysis and computation tools in the training of STEM students from the early stages of their college education. The aim of this project was to engage early-stage college students in the study of real-world data by infusing data-driven and computationally focused modules in the first two years of the mathematics curriculum. The modules were designed to fit naturally into general education mathematics classes, simultaneously reinforcing student learning of the mathematical content and increasing students? ability to work computationally with real-world data. In order to ensure successful adoption of the modules, we provided professional preparation for faculty. We evaluated the impact of the modules on students? disposition towards their mathematics education and the use of technology as a mathematical tool, and the impact of the professional preparation activities.

The three objectives of this project were as follows:

(1)  Develop in-class modules based on real-world data so that students have authentic experiences that support and motivate the investigation of concepts and techniques in calculus and linear algebra;

(2)  Study the impact of the modules on students? disposition towards mathematics and the use of technology as a mathematical tool;

(3)  Prepare faculty to successfully implement data-driven and technology-integrated modules in classrooms.

 

We met the above objectives:

Modules: We developed 30 technology-integrated modules based on real-world data sets for undergraduate mathematics courses for Calculus I, Calculus II, Calculus III and Linear Algebra. Thematically, the modules focused on the environment and sustainability. We created 68 supporting files that were used in MATLAB and/or Octave. During implementation, we found that Octave was not consistently available, and therefore made sister modules for Calculus I that used Microsoft Excel. Modules were tested by graduate students, and then implemented by 16 instructors in 23 courses over the project?s 3 years.

Student Disposition: Prior to the module instruction, students were asked to complete an online survey with both 5-point Likert-scale and free-response questions that address students? disposition toward mathematics. Students who completed the survey were invited to participate in focus groups to collect more detailed information on their views. The process was repeated at the end of the semester (using the same survey).  Data from these surveys and focus groups were synthesized, analyzed, and interpreted, resulting in an article that explains findings about students? interpretation of authenticity, its relationship to their interest in mathematics, and what that relationship implies about learning and teaching.

Professional development: We implemented two professional development workshops for internal participants, and one interactive workshop to recruit and train external participants.  Faculty participants were given a questionnaire before and after professional development, and participated in a focus group after module implementation.  We created a Google Classroom to which participants joined to access modules and supporting materials, surveys to administer to their students, and reflective journal prompts to complete after each module implementation. Many faculty commented that implementing the modules were beneficial for both their students and themselves.
